title: Brit who murdered his fiancee in five-star hotel room is secretly released after just TWO YEARS in prison
text:
Ian Griffin with his new girlfriend Tracey Barker together in a hotel room in Paris for the first time since the death of Kinga Legg (Photo: Albanpix) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The family of a woman beaten to death by her British fiance in a Paris hotel today demanded an inquiry after he was secretly released from prison after less than two years. 
Kinga Legg, a 36-year-old multimillionaire, was found dead in an £800-a-night room at the five-star Bristol after Ian Griffin, now 47, hit her at least 100 times. 
Griffin was jailed for 20 years by judges in Paris in December 2014 after the court heard how he had “massacred” her in an act of cold-blooded murder. 
But in a decision that has infuriated Ms Legg’s family, a French judge ordered Griffin’s release at a closed hearing in October, and he is now living in the Alsace region of eastern France. Kinga Legg Cheshire businessman Ian Griffin is living in the Alsace region of eastern France after being secretly released in October (Photo: MEN) 
The couple shared a home in Oxshott, Surrey, before Ms Legg died, and had been on their way to the south of France to enjoy a holiday. 
Now the "devastated" family of the Polish-born international businesswoman want a "full inquiry" into why Griffin has been released without warning. 
Her cousin, Eva, added: "Oh my God! How can this be? I thought that life meant life – you take a life and you pay for it by forfeiting your own freedom. 
"We all thought he was in jail and that was where he was staying. How could they let him out?" British businessman Ian Griffin (C) arrives, with his lawyer Francis Triboulet (R), at the Criminal court of Paris to attend his trial on December 1, 2014 (Photo: Getty) Hotel Bristol in Paris where Kinga Legg died (Photo: Google) 
Griffin has been posting photos on Facebook, including one in which he plays in the snow with Tracy Baker, a former Dragons' Den contestant, and their two-year-old son. 
Griffin, who suffers from a neurological condition, himself said: "I can’t talk about the conditions of my release or the deal – it was a closed hearing." 
Asked how he thought Miss Legg’s family would react to his release, he said: "I don’t know if they know. 
"Nothing in the world would make me feel better than to make Kinga’s parents feel better. But I can’t." 
During the five-day trial in December 2014, Griffin, who once ran a chain of tanning salons and gadget shops, admitted being addicted to alcohol and anti-depressants at the time of the killing in May 2009. Read More 
But his lawyer’s claim that Griffin’s memory had "disappeared into a black hole" was rubbished by prosecutor Philippe Courroye. 
"It is impossible to believe this state of amnesia, this savage aggression," Mr Courroye said. 
Freed on bail in May 2013, Griffin had said: "She fired a stun gun disguised as a stick of lipstick at me and then punched me in the face, catching me with a ring. 
"I tried to defend myself and she fell over and banged her head on a coffee table." Kinga was hit at least 100 times (Photo: MEN) 
But Mr Courroye said he did not believe any of Griffin’s versions of events, saying the case was a classic one of "violence against women". 
He added that Griffin was a "kind of gigolo" whose business ventures had turned sour and who relied on his wealthy parents for money. 
After killing Ms Legg, Griffin tried to clean the hotel room and phoned reception staff twice to say the couple would be extending their stay at the Bristol. 
Before fleeing to the UK in his Porsche 911, he placed a "Do Not Disturb" sign on the door and told staff his wife was sleeping – evidence that was crucial in convicting him. 
A manhunt was launched and Griffin, who boasted he owned a Lamborghini supercar which once belonged to Eric Clapton, was found sleeping rough in a tent in a wood in Cheshire a week later. He was finally extradited to France, and had a child with Griffin after he was controversially released on bail in 2013. 
At an appeal hearing in April last year, Griffin’s murder conviction was upheld, but his sentence was reduced to 14 years after judges took into account his decision to accept responsibility for what happened, along with his good behaviour while in prison. 
Griffin’s last words in court were: "It was my job to be the protector, the one who dealt with our needs. I almost did. I’m incredibly sorry now." 
Griffin’s lawyers did not respond to requests to comment. Like us on Facebook
